author: JUSTIN WOODARD Staff correspondent
title: Trojans’ momentum builds
text: Josh Flickinger/Beloit Daily News Derek Diehl Turner coach Derek Diehl confers with Tyler Burt during the Trojans’ overtime win over Jefferson Friday night. Posted: Saturday, October 17, 2015 10:00 am Trojans’ momentum builds By JUSTIN WOODARD Staff correspondent beloitdailynews.com | 0 comments BELOIT — Having already finished in a four-way tie for first place in the Rock Valley South Conference at 4-2 with Brodhead/Juda, Big Foot and Clinton, the Trojans went into Friday night’s game against the Jefferson Eagles with a chance to finish with the best overall record of any of the four-way champs. After trailing 28-14 late in the third quarter, the Trojans forced the game into overtime and they came away with the 36-28 victory, improving their overall record to 7-2. “We are extremely proud of overcoming a 14-point deficit and defeating a Division 3 team,” Turner Head Coach Derek Diehl said. “They have over 100 more kids than we do in our school, and traditionally they’ve been a very good football team. We just beat a Division 3 football team. What more is there to say how proud we are?” The Eagles scored first on a 17-yard touchdown run from Hunter Milbrath, his first of three TDs on the night. After a two-point conversion, they led 8-0 with 8:40 to play in the first quarter. But Turner’s athletic sophomore, Juan Reyes, took the ensuing kickoff back 85 yards for a score and after the PAT the score was 8-7 in favor of the Eagles. With 12 seconds left in the first quarter, Milbrath scored on a 75-yard touchdown run. After a missed two-point conversion, the Eagles led 14-7 going into the second quarter. While senior quarterback Seth Smith started the game for the Trojans, he was unable to get much going so Reyes took over. With 6:49 to go in the second quarter, Reyes scored from four yards out and after the made PAT the score was even at 14-14. With 0:13 seconds to go before halftime, Jacob Arnold scored a six yard touchdown and the two-point conversion was no good. The Eagles took a 20-14 lead into halftime. The Trojans received the second half kickoff, but went three-and-out with Smith back in at quarterback. The Eagles killed a lot of clock in the third quarter on their way to another touchdown run from Milbrath and with 4:32 to go in the third quarter they led 28-14. The Trojans had been driving to end the third quarter and less than a minute into the final period, Justin Hansen scored from a yard out and the score was 28-21 after the PAT was good. The Eagles drove to the Trojans’ 1-yard line before turning the ball over on downs. Hansen ripped off a 65-yard run to get into Eagles’ territory and Reyes finished off the drive with a 16-yard touchdown run. Reyes then made his fourth extra point of the night to tie the game at 28-28. In OT, the Trojans got the ball first, and they wasted no time scoring as Hansen ran it in from 20 yards out. Reyes ran in the two-point conversion for a3 6-28 lead. “We’re up and the pressure is on them now,” Diehl said. “If we get a stop we win, and we keep our undefeated streak at home alive. This was a special game for us, with a special cause dedicated to breast cancer awareness.” The Eagles then got their opportunity to start from the 25, but they weren’t so successful. After getting down to the Trojans 1-yard line, they came up short again. Turner’s Ethan Burns recovered a fumble to seal the victory.
